questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to the office with a 6-month history of pain in the left deep buttock area that occasionally radiates to the left leg and intensifies during prolonged periods of sitting. She also reports discomfort when climbing stairs. She denies any trauma. Physical examination reveals localized tenderness over the left gluteal region between the lateral edge of the sacrum and the greater trochanter and an externally rotated left lower extremity. Neurological examination reveals no deficits. In addition to other osteopathic management strategies, you decide to teach the patient a stretching exercise for the affected muscle. Which of the following describes the most appropriate stretching exercise for this patient's condition?

choices.text: Lie supine, flex left hip, bring left knee into extension
Stand with right leg forward and knee flexed, lean forward
Stand, cross left leg behind the right, lean to the right
Lie supine, cross left ankle over right knee, pull right knee toward chest
Lie supine, flex left knee and hip, bring left hip into external rotation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lying supine, flexing the left hip, and bringing the left knee into extension stretches the hamstrings and is used for hamstring sprain. This condition manifests with pain in the posterior thigh and can lead to posterior innominate rotation dysfunction.

B) INCORRECT:

Standing with the right leg forward and knee flexed, then leaning forward, primarily stretches the left hip flexors and psoas muscle and is used in psoas syndrome. This condition also manifests with pain that is aggravated by sitting for long periods and that radiates, but the corresponding tender point would be located 1 cm medial to the anterior superior iliac spine.

C) INCORRECT:

Standing and crossing the left leg behind the right, then leaning to the right, primarily stretches the iliotibial band and is beneficial in iliotibial band syndrome, which typically manifests with pain and tenderness on palpation in the lateral knee.

D) CORRECT:

A spasmed and tight piriformis muscle can cause external rotation of the hip and sciatic nerve entrapment, leading to buttock pain and sciatic, nerve-related paresthesia (piriformis syndrome). The treatment of piriformis syndrome involves osteopathic manipulative therapy (e.g., counterstrain to the piriformis tender point) and exercises that stretch and strengthen the piriformis muscle. Lying supine, crossing the left ankle over the right knee, and pulling the right knee toward the chest stretches the left piriformis muscle. A similar stretch in the prone position involves lifting the chest with the hands on the floor and keeping the unaffected leg extended behind, while the affected leg is in front with the knee flexed and the hip abducted.
Image Description:

Dorsal view

E) INCORRECT:

Lying supine, flexing the left knee and hip, and bringing the left hip into external rotation primarily stretches the left-sided hip adductors and is used for hip adductor sprain. This condition manifests with pain in the groin and inner thigh area, pain with internal hip rotation, and pain when extending the knee.
questions.hint: Pain in the deep gluteal region exacerbated by sitting for prolonged periods and sciatica (i.e., buttock pain that radiates down the leg) indicates piriformis syndrome.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the office with a 2-week history of right knee pain. The patient says that during the past month, she has been preparing for a half-marathon by running at least 4 miles daily. Physical examination of the right leg reveals tenderness to palpation of the lateral knee; the skin over the knee is dry and intact. The patient's right foot is held in eversion and dorsiflexion; range of motion is decreased with inversion and plantarflexion. Femoral and pedal pulses are palpable bilaterally. Noble test and Ober test are negative. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Common peroneal nerve compression can occur in fibular fracture or posterior fibular head dysfunction. This condition typically results in foot drop due to weakness in foot eversion and dorsiflexion and sensory deficit of the lateral lower leg and dorsum of the foot. This patient has no signs of fracture or sensory deficit. Furthermore, her foot is held in eversion and dorsiflexion, making another diagnosis more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Iliotibial band syndrome is common in runners and manifests with lateral knee pain. However, negative Noble and Ober tests make this diagnosis unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Posterior fibular head dysfunction manifests with the foot held in inversion and plantarflexion, resulting in restricted pronation (i.e., limited eversion and dorsiflexion). This patient's foot is held in eversion and dorsiflexion and shows restricted supination.

D) INCORRECT:

Anterior talus dysfunction manifests with limited posterior glide of the talus, restricting foot dorsiflexion. This patient presents with restricted plantarflexion, making this diagnosis unlikely.

E) CORRECT:

A foot that is held in eversion and dorsiflexion suggests an anterior fibular head dysfunction (FHD), which is a pronation dysfunction. In anterior FHD, the distal fibula has moved posteriorly, restricting foot inversion and plantarflexion. Other findings in anterior FHD include anterior displacement of the fibular head and posterior displacement of the talus. Spring test would reveal restricted posterior glide of the fibular head and restricted anterior glide of the distal fibula. Anterior FHD can be caused by activities that involve repetitive stress on the fibula (e.g., running).
questions.hint: This type of injury commonly occurs with eversion ankle sprain.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the office with left knee pain that started 2 months after spraining his ankle while playing basketball. The pain worsens with full knee extension. Ibuprofen and icing the knee does not alleviate the pain. The patient mentions that he has had multiple ankle sprains in the past but denies any previous knee pain. Physical examination reveals tenderness on palpation of the lateral aspect of the left knee and restricted anterior glide of the left fibular head. There is no pain or swelling of the left ankle. A radiograph of the left lower extremity reveals no fractures. Further examination is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Restricted anterior glide of the distal fibula
Restricted anterior glide of the talus

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The anterior glide of the distal fibula is restricted in anterior fibular head dysfunction due to the anterior displacement of the fibular head and reciprocal posterior displacement of the distal fibula. This patient has a posterior fibular head dysfunction and therefore the posterior glide of the distal fibula is restricted.

B) CORRECT:

Recurrent supination ankle sprains are a common cause of posterior fibular head dysfunction. During a supination sprain, the tibia rotates internally and the fibular head is displaced posteriorly, resulting in reciprocal anterior displacement of the distal fibula and internal rotation of the talus. In this position, the foot favors supination, which is a combination of plantarflexion, inversion, and adduction. In some cases, posterior fibular head displacement can lead to injury of the common peroneal nerve, which lies behind the proximal fibular head.

C) INCORRECT:

External rotation of the talus is seen in anterior, rather than posterior, fibular head dysfunction. This is due to the anterior displacement of the fibular head and reciprocal posterior displacement of the distal fibula, causing eversion and dorsiflexion of the foot. In patients with posterior fibular head dysfunction, the talus is internally rotated.

D) INCORRECT:

Sensory loss over the sole indicates a tibial nerve injury, which is commonly associated with tibia fractures, Baker cysts, and tarsal tunnel syndrome. Posterior fibular head dysfunction can cause entrapment of the common peroneal nerve, which can manifest with sensory deficit of the lateral lower leg and dorsum of the foot.

E) INCORRECT:

The anterior glide of the distal fibula and talus is restricted in anterior fibular head dysfunction due to the anterior displacement of the fibular head and reciprocal posterior displacement of the distal fibula and talus. This patient has a posterior fibular head dysfunction and therefore the posterior glide of the distal fibula and talus is restricted.
questions.hint: Restricted anterior glide of the fibular head after an ankle sprain is consistent with posterior fibular head dysfunction, which is a supination dysfunction.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the office with left knee pain that started 2 months after spraining his ankle while playing basketball. The pain worsens with full knee extension. Ibuprofen and icing the knee does not alleviate the pain. The patient mentions that he has had multiple ankle sprains in the past but denies any previous knee pain. Physical examination reveals tenderness on palpation of the lateral aspect of the left knee and restricted anterior glide of the left fibular head. There is no pain or swelling of the left ankle. A radiograph of the left lower extremity reveals no fractures. He is diagnosed with a posterior fibular head dysfunction. The patient consents to high velocity, low amplitude (HVLA) manipulation. To treat this patient with HVLA, the physician should

choices.text: internally rotate the tibia and dorsiflex the foot
externally rotate the tibia and invert the foot
externally rotate the tibia and dorsiflex the foot
externally rotate the tibia and plantarflex the foot
internally rotate the tibia and plantarflex the foot

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dorsiflexion of the foot moves the fibular head anteriorly toward the restrictive barrier. However, internal rotation of the tibia moves the fibular head posteriorly, away from the restrictive barrier.

B) INCORRECT:

External rotation of the tibia moves the fibular head anteriorly toward the restrictive barrier. However, inversion of the foot moves the fibular head posteriorly, away from the restrictive barrier.

C) CORRECT:

To perform HVLA for posterior fibular head dysfunction, the patient is positioned supine with hip and knee bent at 90. The physician's index finger of the thrusting hand is then placed on the posterior aspect of the fibular head. To move the fibular head anteriorly toward the restrictive barrier, the physician externally rotates the tibia and dorsiflexes the foot with the opposite hand. An anterior-directed thrust is then applied to the fibular head while rapidly further flexing the knee.

D) INCORRECT:

External rotation of the tibia moves the fibular head anteriorly toward the restrictive barrier. However, plantarflexion of the foot moves the fibular head posteriorly, away from the restrictive barrier.

E) INCORRECT:

This position would move the fibular head posteriorly and is the correct position to perform HVLA in an anterior fibular head dysfunction. To engage the restrictive barrier in a posterior fibular head dysfunction, the fibular head needs to move anteriorly.
questions.hint: Posterior fibular head dysfunction is a supination dysfunction. To perform HVLA, the restrictive barrier of the fibular head needs to be engaged.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of low back pain. She says she feels unbalanced when walking. On questioning, the patient denies any trauma. Medical history reveals hypertension and osteoporosis. Physical examination reveals a structural leg length discrepancy, with the right leg a  inch shorter than the left. No other abnormalities are noted. The most appropriate initial treatment for this patient's leg length discrepancy is
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Replacement of the full leg length discrepancy is only recommended in patients who have experienced a sudden change in leg length, e.g., due to trauma or hip replacement.

B) INCORRECT:

An ipsilateral anterior sole lift is indicated in patients with a leg length discrepancy that requires a correction larger than an inch. This patient has a total leg length discrepancy of an inch, making heel lift therapy the most appropriate treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

1/8th inch is the initial heel lift thickness recommended for young and otherwise healthy patients with a leg length discrepancy. As this patient is older and has osteoporosis, a different initial heel lift is more appropriate.

D) INCORRECT:

inch is the maximum heel lift thickness that can be applied inside a shoe; it is not a recommendation for an initial heel lift.

E) CORRECT:

1/16th inch is the initial heel lift thickness recommended for patients who are older, in acute pain, or have predisposing conditions (e.g., arthritis, osteoporosis). The heel lift thickness is then increased by another 1/16th inch every two weeks until a final heel lift thickness of of the initially measured discrepancy is reached. In young and otherwise healthy patients, the recommended initial heel lift thickness is 1/8th inch, which is increased by another 1/8th inch every two weeks. In general, the maximum possible heel lift thickness is an inch.
questions.hint: The choice of heel lift therapy is based on patient characteristics (e.g., age, comorbidities) and the etiology of the leg length discrepancy.
